Details: Both outputs provide comprehensive test case frameworks for Azure Synapse to Fabric SQL conversion validation. AAVA_Agent delivers more detailed SQLAlchemy implementation with 10 test cases and robust error handling, while Ascendion_AAVA_Agent provides cleaner Pandas-based approach with similar coverage. Key differences include implementation methodology (SQLAlchemy vs Pandas), error handling sophistication, and code structure organization.

Both outputs address identical core requirements: dimension table population testing, data quality validation, and edge case handling. They implement the same business logic filters (institution_id length > 3, corporation_name not starting with 'TEST', processing_group exclusions). Minor semantic differences in error handling approaches and test fixture design patterns.

Similar overall structure with test case tables, Pytest implementations, and helper functions. AAVA_Agent uses more granular function decomposition with separate setup/teardown utilities, while Ascendion_AAVA_Agent employs integrated fixture patterns. Both follow standard Pytest conventions but differ in database simulation approaches (SQLAlchemy tables vs Pandas DataFrames).

Syntactically correct Python code with proper SQLAlchemy usage, valid table definitions, and correct Pytest decorators. Minor issues: potential undefined variable references in lines 150-160 for table cleanup operations, and some inconsistent parameter passing in populate_dimensions function calls.

Generally correct Python syntax with proper Pandas operations and SQLAlchemy integration. Issues identified: missing error handling in run_fabric_merge_logic function (lines 75-85), potential DataFrame operation failures without null checks (lines 140-150), and inconsistent exception handling patterns.

Both outputs demonstrate high syntactic correctness with minor implementation issues that don't affect core functionality. Average correctness score reflects solid Python/SQL knowledge with room for improvement in error handling robustness.

Improve variable scope management in table cleanup operations and standardize parameter passing in populate_dimensions function. Consider adding more explicit type hints and docstrings for better maintainability.

Enhance error handling in run_fabric_merge_logic function with try-catch blocks. Add null checks before DataFrame operations to prevent runtime errors. Standardize exception handling patterns across all test cases.

Both implementations would benefit from: 1) Consistent logging frameworks for test execution tracking, 2) Parameterized test configurations for different environments, 3) Integration with CI/CD pipeline validation hooks, 4) Performance benchmarking for large dataset scenarios.
